div.p: We show that the most popular method to simulate Bose-Einstein (BE) interference effects predicts negligible correlations between identical pions originating from the hadronic decay of different W𝑊italic-WW’s produced in e+⁢e-→W+⁢W-→4⁢jets→superscript𝑒superscript𝑒superscript𝑊superscript𝑊→4jetsitalic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARROW:to italic-W POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-W POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARROW:to NUMBER:4 ATOM:jetse^{+}e^{-}\to W^{+}W^{-}\to 4\;\hbox{\rm jets} at typical linear collider energies.

p.span: Bose-Einstein Correlations in e+⁢e-→W+⁢W-bold-→superscript𝑒superscript𝑒superscript𝑊superscript𝑊bold-italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:bold-plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end bold-italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:bold-minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARROW:bold-to bold-italic-W POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:bold-plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end bold-italic-W POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:bold-minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ende^{+}e^{-}\to W^{+}W^{-}

S. V. Chekanova𝑎FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-a FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{a}, A. De Roeckb𝑏FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-b FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{b} and E.A. De Wolfc𝑐FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{c}
Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 S. Cass Avenue, Argonne, IL 60439 USA
Deutsches Electron-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, D-22603, Hamburg, FRG
Department of Physics, Universitaire Instelling Antwerp, B-2610 Wilrijk, Belgium

br.p: Proceedings of the Workshop ”Physics Studies for a Future Linear Collider”,

div.p: It is known that the Bose-Einstein (BE) effect can produce a systematic uncertainty on the W𝑊italic-WW mass measurement in the process e+⁢e-→W+⁢W-→4⁢jets→superscript𝑒superscript𝑒superscript𝑊superscript𝑊→4jetsitalic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARROW:to italic-W POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-W POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARROW:to NUMBER:4 ATOM:jetse^{+}e^{-}\to W^{+}W^{-}\to 4\;\hbox{\rm jets}. For the LEP2 experiments, this uncertainty can be serious [1] if it is as large as expected from the standard BE simulation included in the PYTHIA/JETSET Monte Carlo model [2]. Considering that the TESLA linear collider (LC) will make it possible to study e+⁢e-superscript𝑒superscript𝑒italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ende^{+}e^{-} annihilation with much larger statistics and at much higher centre-of-mass-energy, it is important to understand how strongly the W𝑊italic-WW-mass measurement at a LC could be affected by the BE effect.

In this study we use the most popular and simplest BE simulation technique based on the LUBOEI algorithm, as included in PYTHIA/JETSET model. It is known that this algorithm has a strong effect on the W𝑊italic-WW-mass reconstruction and the systematic uncertainties on the W𝑊italic-WW mass can be as large as 50 MeV at LEP2 energies[3]. Other methods of BE simulation usually show much smaller uncertainties at LEP2 energies (see [4] for recent reviews).

In this paper we investigate the BE correlations at TESLA energies using the tools proposed in [5] and [6], without attempts to calculate shifts of the W𝑊italic-WW mass for a particular reconstruction method. By comparing the behaviour of the correlations with those observed at LEP2 energies, quantitative information can be obtained on possible effects on W𝑊italic-WW mass measurements.
To analyse the BE correlations, we use the following two methods:
1) Division method [5]. Here the correlations are measured using the ratio:

semantics.annotation: italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:ww POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( ADDOP:plus-or-minus PUNCT:, ADDOP:plus-or-minus CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:w POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( ADDOP:plus-or-minus PUNCT:, ADDOP:plus-or-minus CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:ww POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( ADDOP:plus PUNCT:, ADDOP:minus CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:w POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( ADDOP:plus PUNCT:, ADDOP:minus CLOSE:) ARG:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where ρwwsuperscript𝜌wwitalic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:ww POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\rho^{\mbox{ww}} and ρwsuperscript𝜌witalic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:w POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\rho^{\mbox{w}} are the two-particle densities for 4 and 2-jet hadronic W𝑊italic-WW decays, respectively, and (±,±)plus-or-minusplus-or-minusOPEN:( ADDOP:plus-or-minus PUNCT:, ADDOP:plus-or-minus CLOSE:)(\pm,\pm) and (+,-)OPEN:( ADDOP:plus PUNCT:, ADDOP:minus CLOSE:)(+,-) denote like-charge and unlike-charge particle combinations. With this definition, R*superscript𝑅italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR^{*} is unity if there is no cross-talk between two W𝑊italic-WW’s. Thus R*superscript𝑅italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR^{*} can be used as an indicator of BE interference between hadrons from different W𝑊italic-WW bosons. We note that this quantity resembles the standard BE correlation function when unlike-charged particles are used as a reference, but has, in fact, little to do with it [6].

semantics.annotation: italic-delta italic-rho RELOP:equals italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:ww POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( ADDOP:plus-or-minus PUNCT:, ADDOP:plus-or-minus CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:w POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( ADDOP:plus-or-minus PUNCT:, ADDOP:plus-or-minus CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:ww POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( ADDOP:plus PUNCT:, ADDOP:minus CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:w POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( ADDOP:plus PUNCT:, ADDOP:minus CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: In the absence of cross-talk between W𝑊italic-WW’s, one has δ⁢ρ=0𝛿𝜌0italic-delta italic-rho RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\delta\rho=0. In the following we use 1+δ⁢ρ1𝛿𝜌NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-delta italic-rho1+\delta\rho, rather than (2) in analogy with R*superscript𝑅italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR^{*}.

The two methods differ mainly in the fact that, for δ⁢ρ𝛿𝜌italic-delta italic-rho\delta\rho the so-called mixing terms (terms determined by the product of single-particle densities) cancel, whereas such mixing terms are still present in the method 1, and largely determine the behaviour of R*superscript𝑅italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR^{*} in the case of cross-talk between W𝑊italic-WW bosons [6].

Results for both methods, using the LUBOEI algorithm, have been presented for LEP2 energies in [6]. About 20K WW events were generated at s=190𝑠190italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:190\sqrt{s}=190 GeV. A clear enhancement of R*superscript𝑅italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR^{*} and δ⁢ρ𝛿𝜌italic-delta italic-rho\delta\rho was observed when the squared 4-momentum difference Q12≡-(p1-p2)2subscript𝑄12superscriptsubscript𝑝1subscript𝑝22italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to italic-square-root ARG:start ADDOP:minus OPEN:( italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:endQ_{12}\equiv\sqrt{-(p_{1}-p_{2})^{2}} between two like-sign particles decreases (see Fig. 8 and 9 of [6]).

Here we present results of a similar study at s=180𝑠180italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:180\sqrt{s}=180 GeV and s=500𝑠500italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:500\sqrt{s}=500 GeV, for a LC. The LC is expected to operate at s=500𝑠500italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:500\sqrt{s}=500 GeV most of the time, collecting an integrated luminosity of 200 fb-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1} per year. The TESLA proposal for the LC will include an option to run at smaller beam energies, down to s=90𝑠90italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:90\sqrt{s}=90 GeV, but with reduced luminosity. If the physics motivation is sufficiently strong, TESLA can also run at energies slightly above the W⁢W𝑊𝑊italic-W italic-WWW threshold, e.g. at s=𝑠absentitalic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals\sqrt{s}= 180 or 200 GeV. Event samples which can reasonably expected to be collected at this energy, amount to 10-20 fb-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, i.e. about 20 times larger than the data samples collected at LEP2.

The results for R*superscript𝑅italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR^{*} and 1+δ⁢ρ1𝛿𝜌NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-delta italic-rho1+\delta\rho are shown in Fig. 2 and Fig. 2. The solid lines in the figures correspond to the case of no BE correlations. At each energy 200K W⁢W𝑊𝑊italic-W italic-WWW events were generated, corresponding to a luminosity of 15 fb-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1} and 30 fb-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1} at s=180𝑠180italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:180\sqrt{s}=180 GeV and s=500𝑠500italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:500\sqrt{s}=500 GeV, respectively.

The figures show no increase of R*superscript𝑅italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR^{*} and 1+δ⁢ρ1𝛿𝜌NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-delta italic-rho1+\delta\rho for small Q12subscript𝑄12italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endQ_{12} at s=500𝑠500italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:500\sqrt{s}=500 GeV, whereas BE correlations are clearly seen at 180 GeV. At an intermediate energy, s=300𝑠300italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:300\sqrt{s}=300 GeV, both correlation quantities have also been studied (not shown). The BE effect was found to be much smaller than that at s=180𝑠180italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:180\sqrt{s}=180 GeV. Therefore, in order to detect this effect at s=300𝑠300italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:300\sqrt{s}=300 GeV much higher statistics than at LEP is needed.

The statistics used for the present paper are ten times larger than that used for LEP2 studies [6]. The figures illustrate that, with the much higher statistics expected at LC more details in the behaviour of BE correlations can be observed, especially for 1+δ⁢ρ1𝛿𝜌NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-delta italic-rho1+\delta\rho. This correlation function is slightly below unity for Q12∼0.3-1.2similar-tosubscript𝑄120.31.2italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.3 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1.2Q_{12}\sim 0.3-1.2 GeV and has a rather complex structure. This is much less evident for R*superscript𝑅italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR^{*}, where the details of the genuine correlations are hidden due to the presence of large mixing terms in the definition (1).

Our results demonstrate that BE correlations between hadrons from different W𝑊italic-WW’s can be studied at energies close to the W⁢W𝑊𝑊italic-W italic-WWW threshold. At much higher energies the effect is negligible. This is related to the large phase space available for secondary particles from hadronic W𝑊italic-WW decays at high energy, and the small probability for two identical secondary particles from different W𝑊italic-WW’s to be emitted close in Q12subscript𝑄12italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endQ_{12} -phase space111A similar observation was made in [7].

In conclusion, studies at s=500𝑠500italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:500\sqrt{s}=500 GeV do not indicate the presence of Bose-Einstein correlations between identical hadrons from decays of different W𝑊italic-WW bosons for realistic statistics attainable at a LC. The systematic uncertainty on a measurement of the W𝑊italic-WW mass caused by these correlations is therefore expected to be negligible. This result is based on the most popular method to simulate BE correlations (LUBOEI in PYTHIA/JETSET) and two different experimental techniques. The LUBOEI algorithm is known to produce the largest effect on the W𝑊italic-WW mass reconstruction at LEP2 energies. It is therefore reasonable to expect that the use of other available models, known to lead to smaller uncertainties on the reconstruction of W𝑊italic-WW mass, can only strengthen the above conclusion. However when the LC will be operated at an energy close to but above the W⁢W𝑊𝑊italic-W italic-WWW threshold, collecting event samples of the order of 10-20 fb-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, BE effects between different W𝑊italic-WW’s can be studied with uncanny precision.

L. Lönnblad, Proc. of the Workshop ”Correlations and Fluctuations”, Ed. T. Csörgó et al. Matrahaza, Hungary 1998 (World Scientific, 1999) p.1;
W. Kittel, Interconnection Effects and W+⁢W-superscript𝑊superscript𝑊italic-W POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-W POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endW^{+}W^{-} Decays (a critical (p)(re)view), hep-ph/9905394, to be published in Proc. Recontres de Moriond 1998.
DELPHI Coll., P. Abreu et al., Phys. Lett. B 401 (1997) 181
S. V. Chekanov, E. A. De Wolf, W. Kittel, Eur. J. Phys. C 6 (1999) 403
J. Schieck, to appear in “Physics Studies for a Future Linear Collider”, R. Heuer, F. Richard and P. Zerwas Eds., DESY123F (2000).

figure.figcaption: Figure 1: R*superscript𝑅italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR^{*} for PYTHIA Monte Carlo model without and with BE correlations at s=180,500𝑠180500italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:180 PUNCT:, NUMBER:500\sqrt{s}=180,500 GeV. The solid line corresponds to the model without BE effect.

Figure 2: 1+δ⁢ρ1𝛿𝜌NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-delta italic-rho1+\delta\rho for PYTHIA Monte Carlo model without and with BE correlations at s=180,500𝑠180500italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:180 PUNCT:, NUMBER:500\sqrt{s}=180,500 GeV. The solid line corresponds to the model without BE effect.
